Solange's latest single, Losing You, her first in four years, is a good indication of why Pitchfork once insisted she had "impeccable taste". It's short, sweet, bubbly indie pop that sounds like it was made in New York at some point between 1979 and 1981, back when the city was covered in graffiti and Madonna was waving her demos under Seymour Stein's nose. Co-written and produced by Dev Hynes (Lightspeed Champion, Blood Orange) and benefiting from a sepia-tinged video starring an obscure group of African sartorialists called Le Sapeurs, Losing You completes a decade in which Solange has gone from pop underdog to, well, queen of hipsters.

"Hipster? I despise that word!" the 26-year-old says, laughing, from her home in New York. Fair enough. Nobody wants to embrace the term, least of all hipsters. Yet it's hard to think of a more appropriate shorthand for her career. "Come on," she counters. "It's just a lazy way to describe someone who doesn't define themselves in a narrow way, culturally speaking."

I approached Solange fearing that she might be a spiky interviewee, in part due to an interview she gave Fox 5 in 2008, which subsequently went viral, in which she berated a presenter for asking about her sister. In fact, she explains, she could hear the Fox team mocking her family off-air, and thought they should know it was disrespectful. "If I was a male rapper responding in that way, it would have been no big deal," she says. "But when a black woman stands up for herself suddenly she has an attitude problem." Besides, she adds, who cares? It's Fox.

As it turns out, she's perfectly happy to discuss Beyoncé. "My sister and I were not allowed expensive clothes. We so badly wanted these Fila sneakers as kids but my mother took us down to the flea market and got imitation ones. Look at the early Destiny's Child videos, you'll see!" she says, of their unflashy childhood.

'Hipster? I despise that word. It's just a lazy way to describe someone who doesn't define themselves in a narrow way'

Not spiky, then, but, by her own admission, a little stubborn. It was always this way. As a child she was deeply attached to her tap shoes and could not be prised away from them. "At a work party of my dad's, my sister wore this cute little dress and I went stomping along in my tap shoes. They make a lot of noise on a hard floor."

When Solange was 14, and starting her pop career after signing to Columbia Records, that stubborness reared up, following a family trip to Jamaica. "I just fell in love with Rastafarian culture, in that way one does at that age, in that you get things a little wrong," she recalls. "I grew my hair right down to my butt, and when I got home I tried making reggae music. My label's reaction was, 'What. The Hell. Is this?'"

Most 14-year-olds on the brink of releasing their first album might back down, but Solange stuck to her guns, evidence of which can be seen in the artwork for Solo Star, which shows the singer wearing a beanie hat in Rastafarian colours. She cracks up: "Honestly, I'm proud of that album because it reminds me that I did it my way, even if some of it seems a bit... ridiculous now." Solo Star reached No 49 on the Billboard chart. She didn't make another album for Columbia.

Instead she married a college boy, moved to Idaho and had a baby, all by the ripe old age of 17. "In retrospect, it was very young to get started on those things, but I had been working since I was 13, so I felt I had a head start. I'm sure deep down my parents were not completely thrilled, but I had my own money. I'd been working for five years by then, so there wasn't much they could do but offer moral support, which they did." The sound, perhaps, of those tap shoes still making their own noise.

Solange started writing her next album, Sol-Angel And The Hadley St Dreams, in 2004, though it didn't see the light of day until 2008. "I grew up around soul – Aretha, Marvin Gaye – so this was my acknowledgement of love for that music." Sol-Angel was a smart, exuberant take on 60s Motown but, she says, "It was actually quite an isolating time for me. I was away from my family, and I loved being a mother, but everything was very new." In the four years it took to be released, Solange got divorced and moved to Los Angeles, though ultimately it was "label issues" that saw Sol-Angel stuttering to life outside the studio. In a not-unrelated twist, Solange self-released the mellifluous diss track Fuck The Industry (Signed Sincerely), which is a good indication of how she felt about Geffen, her record label at the time.

'I walked in and Dev was playing this beat, and it was like a lightbulb went off … and he was dressed as a wizard, which helped'

She went quiet again until 2010, when she met Dev Hynes. "One night a friend of mine, the rapper Theophilus London, called me up and said, 'You have to meet my friend.' I walked in and Dev was standing there, playing this beat, and it was like a lightbulb went off. I thought, 'That's the sound I've been waiting for.' I said to my boyfriend, 'I've found the person I want to make my album with.' He said, 'Don't you want to hear more than one of his songs?'" The next time they met, Dev showed Solange a playlist that included Chaka Khan and Jimmy Jay, a French 80s hip-hop artist. "I had practically the same playlist at home! It felt like, 'This has happened for a reason.' Oh, and Dev was dressed as a wizard at the time, which helped."

Solange won't share album details, even when pressed, because "we've still got to put all the little finishing touches to it". Unlike the polite detachment of Solange circa 2002, her coyness now seems to be down to being protective of a project she's clearly excited about, although shortly after we spoke, she confirmed to Pitchfork (where else?) that a seven-track EP called True would be released at the end of November.

She did let slip that the new songs are sad, though not because she's miserable. "Dev had just broken up with his girlfriend, so we closed ourselves away in this house in Santa Barbara and wrote the story of the end of his relationship." So the album is actually all about someone else's pain? "That's right! I'm actually pretty happy right now. But 'I'm happy!' doesn't really work over 12 songs, does it?"
